title: Zambia president says 2019 economic growth forecast cut to 2%
text:
Zambian President Edgar Lungu reacts after participating in a discussion at the World Economic Forum on Africa 2017 meeting in Durban, South Africa May 4, 2017. REUTERS/Rogan Ward/File Photo

LUSAKA (Reuters) - Zambia has cut its 2019 economic growth forecast to around 2% from an initial projection of 4%, President Edgar Lungu said on Friday.

Lungu said in a state of the nation address in parliament that adverse weather conditions will negatively affect growth this year.

“It is being revised downwards to about 2 % on account of adverse weather conditions which have affected the energy and agricultural sectors,” Lungu said.

Lungu said Africa’s second-largest copper producer would strive to dismantle domestic arrears and maintain debt within sustainable levels.

Zambia’s external debt rose to $10.05 billion at the end of 2018, compared with $8.74 billion a year earlier, raising fears that the southern African country is headed for a debt crisis.
